history.content: Im in the same position. Personally im doing data science bc its extremely close to CS and I don't have to "throw away" the CS coursework I've already done. I think Data Science might be a bit better if you want to do SWE or data analytics work though im not sure.

children.subject: I don't think any of them make getting into any cs class any easier, so it doesn't really matter which you choose. I would also choose DS though since to a recruiter that may be more relatable to cs than applied math (just my guess).
But don't we have an option to take a lot of cs classes in applied math cs cluster also?
Another side note: stats also has a CS cluster.

I am not sure if this is the answer you want but just consider it as a different perspective: why not take data 100 and/or stats 134/140 to get a feeling of what data science/stats is like? I was in the same boat but then realized CS is not my calling. I took data 100 and really enjoyed the data analytics techniques, which helped me to find the research I'm helping out with now. Then I took stats 140 and realized I really enjoyed the concepts in stats (trust me it's completely different from 70), something I wouldn't have dreamed of prior to college. So you never know. It's possible you would still find yourself enjoying CS, then maybe you can talk to the advisor to find out more about the next steps.

A side note for math though: Math upper divs are very different from the lower divs. I'm not sure if you have taken any math upper divs, so you might really like them or not so much. I would suggest you take math 110 and/or 113 to see if you like them. Probably don't take 104 as your first math upper div since it's considered the harder ones among the intro math upper divs

Another side note: you can join the data science and/or stats Piazza if you haven't already. 

Sorry for the lengthy follow up and good luck : ) !!

An alternative viewpoint: unlike the student answer, I don't believe doing Applied Math is "throwing away the CS coursework you've done." I am an Applied Math-CS double major, and I strongly believe that the mathematical and analytical skills you gain from a math major apply *directly* to computer science. Some of the best computer scientists I have met in industry were in fact math bachelors and/or PhDs, with little to no formal training in CS.

Given that you said you like math more, I encourage you to follow your passion! Also, regardless of the major you choose, you can always take CS courses a la carte if you want. Good luck!

Applied math is probably better since it has its own department, unlike data science. Also, data science is really new so there are probably a lot of beauraucratic and administrative issues that haven’t been totally cleared out yet. 

Besides, if you do applied math then you can do the CS cluster and that’s 3 CS courses, which is about the same number you’d take as a DS major.

history.content:
It seems like i cannot declare cs.

               I am confused whether i should declare data science or applied math . I like math more but still does anybody has any tips on how do I decide whether to major in applied math or data science

                                          Thank you!

                                        Abayjeet Singh
history.subject: Data science vs applied math
